events.event_description: U.S. shale gas production declined by 1% to 81.2 Bcf/d in the first nine months of 2024, marking the first potential annual decrease since 2000.
events.citation: Total U.S. shale gas production from January through September 2024 declined by about 1%, to 81.2 billion cubic feet per day (Bcf/d), compared with the same period in 2023

events.event_description: Shale gas production in Haynesville and Utica plays showed significant declines, with Haynesville decreasing 12% and Utica declining 10% from January through September 2024.
events.citation: From January through September 2024, shale gas production decreased by 12% (1.8 Bcf/d) in the Haynesville and by 10% (0.6 Bcf/d) in the Utica compared with the same period in 2023

events.event_description: The Permian play experienced a 10% growth in shale gas production, increasing by 1.6 Bcf/d alongside rising oil production.
events.citation: At the same time, shale gas production in the Permian play grew by 10% (1.6 Bcf/d). Production in the Marcellus play, which leads U.S. shale gas production, remained flat

events.event_description: Henry Hub natural gas prices hit record lows in first half of 2024, causing operators in Haynesville and Appalachian Basin to shut in production.
events.citation: The U.S. benchmark Henry Hub daily natural gas price has generally declined since August 2022 and reached record lows in the first half of 2024, making drilling natural gas wells less profitable, particularly in the Haynesville

events.event_description: The number of operating rigs in Haynesville fell to 33 in September 2024, marking a 53% decrease from January 2023 and the lowest level since July 2020.
events.citation: In the Haynesville, an average of 33 rigs were in operation in September 2024, 53% fewer than in January 2023. The number of rigs operating in the Haynesville in September was the lowest it has been since July 2020
